chapter.title: Summary of Findings – Data Collection and Transmission for FDA Medical Device Development Tools

section.title: Purpose
section.para: Integrated Knowledge Management (IKM) is a multi-faceted approach to managing data and industry-wide knowledge. The primary goal of IKM in the healthcare sector is to advance patient health outcomes and organizational operations by improving the accuracy, quality, and interoperability of healthcare data. While a well-structured and comprehensive approach to IKM has the potential to positively impact the entire healthcare field, this deliverable will more specifically explore how IKM, Terminology Knowledge Architecture (Tinkar), and Komet can support the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA’s) Medical Device Development Tools (MDDT) program and future submitters achieve their goals.

section.title: Background
section.para: Over the last two years, our team has been working to develop an IKM reference implementation in the form of Komet. Komet is an application that supports comprehensive IKM of various healthcare terminology standards, like Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes (LOINC®), Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT®), and RxNorm. Komet employs Terminology Knowledge Architecture (Tinkar), a self-describing data structure and logical model, to provide a standardized and repeatable way of representing these various clinical terminology standards. Tinkar can transform data into both Protocol Buffers (Protobuf) and the Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) data exchange standard to export and transmit data to other system. To demonstrate the real-world applicability of Komet and IKM, our team explored how it could contribute to FDA goals.

The MDDT program is an FDA initiative that aims to improve the process for device development, evaluation, and innovation by providing a standardized way to qualify the tools that medical devices use, including biomarker tests, various outcome measures, sensors, and more. The FDA medical device review and approval process has a variety of submission pathways, with a high-level overview of the overarching process outline below. FDA Device Submission Process
If a device uses a qualified MDDT tool, the device sponsor can ensure FDA approval of that specific tool without needing to undergo additional, duplicative review [1], IKM and Tinkar have the potential to support the MDDT program in two key ways:

listitem.para: Submitting Komet, Tinkar, and our overall IKM approach to the MDDT program as a tool for review and approval to help FDA improve the predictability and efficiency of medical device development and review.

Using Komet, Tinkar, and our overall IKM approach as a standardized and repeatable way to represent the various qualified tools, devices, and tests approved through the initiative and map them to disparate terminology standards.

section.title: Komet as a Tool
section.para: The MDDT program identifies four categories for submitted tools, including an “Other” category that assess (or supports assessment of) safety, effectiveness, or performance for a medical device [2]. Komet and our work could fall within this category as an open-source database and validation tool that ensures medical devices represent data, results, analytes, codes, and other critical information associated with devices in a standardized and accurate way. Komet could serve as a tool for a wide range of devices submitted to FDA via established pathways that would facilitate their review and approval:

listitem.para: 501(K) submissions: Devices in the 501(k) premarket submission process argue that their device is as safe and effective as an existing and equivalent device that is already on the market. Using Komet and Tinkar as a database could be used to demonstrate how both devices use the same, or equivalent, codes to represent the various tests, analytes, results, and values being captured [3].

FDA Premarket Approval (PMA) Submissions: Devices in the PMA approval process possess substantial risks, support human life, and/or are significantly involved in the prevention of negative health outcomes in humans. Given this risk to human health and safety, Komet, Tinkar, and our standardized representation of data across terminology standards could validate that these devices can accurately transmit encoded information to a variety of health information systems – including Electronic Health Records (EHRs), Laboratory information Systems (LISs), and more – without the loss of structure, meaning, or critical associated concepts. Komet can be used to ensure these devices can not only capture this information in their local systems but can also transmit the information to other systems involved in the delivery of patient care to demonstrate their ability to meet their intended purpose of protecting human life [4].

De Novo Submissions: Devices in the De Novo approval process represent novel medical devices that lack a comparable existing device to use as a point of comparison. These devices may not have existing ways to be represented using terminology standards. Komet can support the creation of a novel concept that can be used to reference the device submission while collecting data and performing tests. The versioning features within Komet can then be used to retire the temporary concept and update it to the official concepts once they have been created. Using our Status, Time, Author, Module, Path (STAMP) feature, the information associated with the temporary concept, the date the concept was updated, the specific information that was changed when it was updated to the official concept, and more would be stored and could be easily visualized in the timeline feature. As these concepts continue to evolve, Komet would continue to tie critical information to the most recent versions so that historical context and data is not lost [5].

section.para: As an MDDT, Komet could streamline the device review and approval process, reducing the time and resources needed to evaluate products accurately and efficiently. Komet would support a consistent and reliable assessment of other devices that reduces the time it takes to approve products. Once products have been approved, Komet could also continue to support standardized assessments of their safety with high-quality data collection and post-market surveillance that expedites 501(K) submissions, additional continued evaluation of devices, and more.

section.title: Standardized Representation and Transmission of Device Data
Discussion
section.para: Our team explored the possibility and accuracy of end-users using Komet to author or edit an MDDT-related concept in Tinkar, transforming that representation into FHIR, and then transmitting that data to the various terminology standards to provide a way to represent these new tools when there is no formal or standardized concept [6]. We used IKM and Komet to develop Tinkar Terminology Change Sets and versioned knowledge graphs to provide Description Logic for terminology concept definitions. Even when there isn’t an official term or concept code, our Tinkar Change Sets provided an avenue to represent the MDDT tests, tools, and devices in a standardized way. This could serve as both a temporary solution, that could then be identified and mapped as an equivalent concept once Standards Developing Organizations (SDOs) release a formal term, or a permanent solution that could be submitted, validated, and released by SDOs. This document explores how IKM and Tinkar could support the lossless transmission of MDDT data between these devices and health systems, like EHRs and LISs, by normalizing the representation of devices, results, properties, and other pertinent information.

section.title: Performance & Efficiency
section.para: An implementation of the Tinkar data model includes rich semantic details for representing knowledge sources including but not limited to individual concepts, synonyms and descriptions, relationships between terms, language and dialect information, and description logic axioms and robust version history. This rich verbose data set contains complex and highly granular information. Converting this data into a structured format like JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) or Health Level Seven (HL7) FHIR can be challenging due to the intricacy and depth of the data. Finding equivalence between source data elements and Tinkar data elements correctly is crucial when converting Tinkar data into a structured format. However, this process can be difficult and time-consuming, particularly when dealing with complex data sets. Both JSON and HL7 FHIR have their own limitations. For instance, JSON itself isn’t as performant as alternative binary-JSON format representations and HL7 FHIR may not cover all possible healthcare data exchange use cases and scenarios. These limitations can pose challenges when trying to represent a rich verbose data set like a Tinkar database. Our team also found variation between different operating systems when transforming Tinkar data to HL7 FHIR and JSON exports.

section.title: Lossy Representation
section.para: Transforming Tinkar data into JSON or HL7 FHIR risks loss of information or distortion of original data. Thus, maintaining data integrity during this conversion process is a challenge. One significant challenge we faced in implementation of the transform to FHIR is JSON does not support all data types and structures that Tinkar and the source terminologies native formats represent. Therefore, when transforming data from a Tinkar data representation to JSON, there is a risk of losing information that does not fit into the JSON structure. While JSON can handle some complex data structures, it can struggle with deeply nested structures such as description logic axiom definitions for concepts. Furthermore, during the transformation process, valuable metadata (such as timestamps, authorship, or source information) may be lost. This can reduce the utility and context of the transformed data, especially in the context of the STAMP (status, time, author, module, and path) information in Tinkar at the concept-level rather than at the code system level.

section.title: Version History Over Time
section.para: Data standards are constantly evolving. The Tinkar data representation is designed to retain each version of objects persisted as the object changes over time, along with metadata indicating its version identifier, time of creation, creating author, and branch of the version control system on which it was created. Every version of each object must remain available for retrieval and inspection. Keeping up with these changes and ensuring the converted data remains compliant with the updated standards can be challenging, especially with the lossy challenges as described above in the HL7 FHIR format. FHIR terminology resources do not have a clean way of representing rich version history and metadata; we are currently employing a strategy of combining together a HL7 Code System FHIR Resource and HL7 Provenance FHIR Resource but there are details lost such as the Module and Path and can only be exported at the Code System level and not at the individual concept-level.

section.title: Reasoning
section.para: Lossy representation can lead to inefficient querying. If data is not accurately represented, it can be more challenging to perform queries and gain insights from the JSON data. If many concepts are updated in a Tinkar editing environment, then the description logic reasoning can take a long time to execute and have unintended consequences on the results. To mitigate these challenges, it's crucial to plan and execute the transformation process carefully, taking into consideration the data types, structures, and other specific characteristics of the Tinkar database.

section.title: Future Considerations
section.para: As FDA continues to mature the MDDT program, Komet and IKM could support integration with the Laboratory Interoperability Device Reference (LIDR), a centralized repository of standardized codes for laboratory tests, devices, and analyzers. Incorporating LIDR into the MDDT process and requiring participants to transmit their LIDR record, using Komet and IKM, as part of the evaluation process could support further standardization of laboratory device representation [7].

In the coming months, our team plans to unequivocally demonstrate that IKM, and more specifically Komet, provides the general authoring capabilities and features necessary to support LIDR and improve the quality of healthcare data. Komet will provide an authoring environment that can represent a wide range of healthcare systems and terminology standards that also supports exporting data in a FHIR format to map laboratory devices, tools, and results to LOINC® and other standards that LISs can use to represent new concepts. As part of this initiative, our team plans to perform extensive validation exercises at all stages of the workflow to ensure key functionality and data quality. This effort aligns with one of LIDR’s goals to reduce the variance in device representation across laboratories by automating the mapping process or placing the onus of device mapping on the In Vitro Diagnostic (IVD) manufacturer, including reference and tooling.
